Admiral James T. Kirk.Action: Issues a yellow alert and orders shields up and reduced closing speed when confronted with an unknown powerful probe affecting ship systems.
Attempts to isolate the wave causing interference by consulting the science officer and adapting commands accordingly.
Fails to regain control of the ship's thrusters or electronic systems as they are neutralized by the probe.
Faces a Federation Council where he is publicly accused and labeled a renegade and terrorist by the Klingon Ambassador, yet remains composed.
Allows the Klingon Ambassador to use his past actions (theft of a Klingon vessel, murder accusations) against him without immediately refuting the claims in the excerpt.
Defended by Sarek against wrongful accusations; his role in Genesis device emphasized as creation of life, not destruction.
Secretly developing Genesis torpedo and test detonating it, leading to accusations of plotting annihilation of Klingons.
Remains in Vulcan exile with crew on a captured Klingon ship, continuing to lead and make decisions despite political opposition and charges.
Fails to prevent political and legal charges against him by Starfleet and Klingon representatives.
Inspects the Bird of Prey before launch, systematically checks systems status including communications and guidance with crew.
Asks for status on weapons systems and commends Chekov for preparing well for the mission despite short voyage.
Acknowledges and appreciates Scotty's technical improvements and consideration (Dilithium Sequencer upgrade, food replacement).
Gives clear orders to prepare for departure, showing calm leadership.
Engages emotionally with Saavik about his son, showing vulnerability and emotional depth without losing command presence.
Greets Spock warmly by using his first name; shows understanding and patience regarding Spock's condition.
Dismisses Bones' concerns about Spock's readiness without clear assurance; seems uncertain but proceeds anyway.
Grants permission to Spock aboard promptly, demonstrating authority and confidence.
Acknowledges Spock’s disorientation but proceeds with normal command, showing trust and composure.
Ignores Bones' concerns about Spock's impaired state and proceeds with normal operations, displaying some doubt and possible overconfidence.
Directs Mr. Sulu to take them home despite uncertainty about Spock's readiness, reflecting decisiveness but potentially risky judgment.
No direct action or statement presented in the excerpt; no visible involvement in managing the crisis or providing direction at Starfleet Command.
Responds quickly to Uhura’s alert and asks what is wrong, showing concern for the crew and situation.
Despite the distress calls and crisis, maintains communication and seeks understanding from Spock, indicating trust and collaborative spirit.
Addresses Bones with concern and gives clear instructions to stay behind for safety.
Interacts with Uhura respectfully, acknowledging her efforts and capabilities.
Shows patience and open-mindedness by considering Spock's unconventional theory about the message.
Reflects thoughtfully on whales' ancient presence on Earth and expresses concern about the probe's threat to Earth.
Insists on finding an alternative to destroying the probe, showing concern for Earth's safety and willingness to explore other options.
Quickly acknowledges the possibility that whales are the probe's communication target, shows openness to an unusual idea, and thinks about historical context.
Decisively states the necessity to destroy the probe before it destroys Earth, showing decisiveness in crisis.
Engages in discussion seeking alternatives when destruction is futile, demonstrating flexible problem-solving.
Does not immediately accept Spock's assertion that only Earth of the past has whales; asks clarifying questions.
Explains patiently to Scotty about needing to find whales and encourages him confidently to solve the problem.
Uses a lighthearted, friendly comment ('It takes two to tango') to engage Scotty.
Shows trust in Scotty's abilities by simply stating 'You'll work it out, Scotty.'
Dismisses Bones’ skepticism without appearing confrontational, moving the plan forward.
Proposes a risky but innovative plan to travel back in time to save the whales and ultimately stop the probe, showing vision and decisiveness.
Challenges Bones to provide a better idea, demonstrating confidence and leadership in difficult circumstances.
Immediately initiates communication with Starfleet Command upon boarding the Bird of Prey, showing procedural skill and awareness.
Uses a distorted and incomplete communication with Starfleet Command during a chaotic situation, but persists in conveying critical information.
Leads the effort to attempt time travel to save the Humpback Whales, shows understanding of the mission's critical variables.
Asks Spock for clarification on mission details, showing engagement and command oversight.
Demonstrates trust in Spock's memory and expertise without hesitation.
Does not question the risks associated with incomplete data or the reliability of memory-based programming explicitly.
Encourages team by complimenting Spock ('Well done, Mr. Spock').
Listens attentively to Uhura's report and acts on it ('Home in on the strongest signal; descend from orbit').
Acknowledges Spock's concern about being detected and takes precautions ('Quite right, Spock. Mr. Chekov, engage cloaking device!').
Quickly interprets Spock's analysis of pollution to deduce the time period.
Positively acknowledges Spock's input and directs the crew accordingly (homing in on whale songs, descending from orbit).
Recognizes the potential risk of detection and immediately orders the cloaking device engaged.
Questions unusual whale song origin logically, showing critical thinking.
Decides to continue approach despite unclear and potentially risky unknowns.
Shows frustration at technical limitations but engages thoughtfully with Scotty and Spock to find a solution.
Presses for explanations and shows open-mindedness toward Spock's 20th-century solution despite risks.
Divides the team into smaller groups, assigns tasks clearly and practically, gives careful instructions, and shows concern for team safety in an unfamiliar environment.
Flustered response to rude car driver with a mild insult.
Gives clear instructions to crew to spread out and wait, showing leadership without harshness.
Brightly engages with the store owner about the value of his broken glasses, shows lightheartedness.
Carefully divides limited money among friends and encourages a sensible, equitable approach to spending.
Engages Spock warmly with a light, optimistic approach while searching for the whales, smiling at clues like the bus ad and using 'simple logic' playfully.
Expresses empathy and concern about the plight of whales and humanity's destructive behavior.
Expresses excitement and appreciation for the whales, showing genuine interest and positive regard.
Fails to notice Spock's absence during the tour, indicating possible inattentiveness to companions' presence or feelings.
Watches Spock closely with mild shock, pursues Gillian when she rushes off, but lets Spock face the confrontation first and does not intervene immediately.
Assures Gillian that calling the cops won't be necessary and tries to de-escalate the situation.
Encourages Spock in a lighthearted way about using colorful metaphors and trying to explain social nuances.
Suggests to Spock that it is not always necessary to tell the truth and hints at exaggeration as a tactic.
Attempts to de-escalate tension with Gillian by assuring no harm was intended and suggesting cooperation.
Advises Spock on social communication, recognizing Spock’s difficulty with colorful metaphors and the need for strategic truthfulness.
Shows patience and understanding towards Spock’s literal mindset and guides him on exaggeration as a social tool.
Leads a mission involving careful coordination and understanding of technical details, as suggested by the team discussions about reactor coordinates and dangers.
Responds promptly to team communications, approves their plan with confidence, and asks for updates.
Acknowledges the approaching woman from the Institute and decides to engage subtly to gain information.
Keeps his composure and plays it cool when being tracked, not revealing his intent outright.
Acknowledges Gillian's offer of help politely and thanks her.
Rolls eyes at Spock's denial of attending Berkeley, showing mild irritation.
Engages in sincere conversation with Gillian about their intentions and concerns for the whales.
Clarifies and communicates important information clearly regarding the whales and their risk of extinction.
Calmly handles Gillian's hostility and skepticism without losing composure.
Refuses to disclose sensitive information but reassures intent, showing awareness of security and diplomacy.
Engages in dialogue that anticipates and addresses possible objections even when not fully explaining their plans.
Invites Gillian to dinner to ease the tension and promote friendly conversation.
No direct action or decision shown in this excerpt; no indication of competence or incompetence observable.
Responds to Gillian's question about trusting her with an 'Implicitly', showing confident interpersonal judgment.
Shrugs and orders the same meal as Gillian after apparently being blank when looking at menu, indicating a casual or indifferent approach to decision-making in a minor situation.
Shows perceptiveness in recognizing Gillian’s emotional state about the whales, indicating emotional intelligence.
Questions and engages with practical details of Gillian’s plan to save the whales, showing thoughtful and analytical questioning.
Suggests alternative options for the whales' safety, demonstrating problem-solving initiative.
Shows care and concern for the whales' safety and considers difficult possibilities thoughtfully.
Engages in light teasing and playful banter with Gillian, acknowledging chemistry without being dismissive.
Ignores his communicator despite possible urgent calls, focusing on the present moment and conversation.
Uses testy tone telling someone not to call him; then quietly says 'phasers on stun' and wishes good luck
Engages in playful, light-hearted banter with Gillian, demonstrating a sense of humor and openness
Shows persistence in asking Gillian about the whale release despite her teasing
Commands to set phasers on stun and wishes luck before ending communication confidently.
Uses a testy tone when annoyed by the beeper interrupting him.
Engages in casual conversation and reveals his mission clearly when pressed, indicating adaptability and communication skill.
Engages in casual conversation with Gillian, answers her questions openly, and explains his mission sincerely.
Acknowledges Gillian's boundaries when she refuses to share classified information without pressing or showing frustration.
Declines to show off the spaceship when asked, maintaining a respectful distance.
Gives Gillian a brief kiss before leaving, showing a sincere but restrained connection.
Expresses frustration and anger over the possible failure of the mission, emphasizing the stakes for all life on Earth, and shows his emotional vulnerability openly to Spock.
Pressures Gillian for a quick decision to retrieve the whales, showing decisiveness and urgency.
Acts frustrated and emotionally overwhelmed, expressing anger and confusion over the mission's stakes.
Stalks off in frustration leaving Spock behind during a critical moment instead of maintaining composure and leadership.
No direct action, statement, or internal behavior by Kirk is present in the excerpt to assess competence.
Gently reassures Uhura after Chekov's accident, acknowledging her efforts and encouraging her to keep trying.
Expresses frustration and impatience with Scott over slow progress on dilithium crystal re-crystallization.
Welcomes and helps a confused and dazed Gillian after she beams aboard, catching her as she almost faints and reassuring her.
Expresses frustration and shared concern about the missing whales, showing empathy for Gillian's distress.
Expresses concern for Chekov's critical condition and quickly agrees to help despite risks
Seeks Spock's opinion before making medical decisions, showing respect for others' judgment
Orders a plan to impersonate medical personnel to save Chekov, showing resourcefulness and care
Immediately responds to Uhura's call and shows concern for Chekov's condition.
Considers advice from Bones and Spock about intervening in Chekov's medical care before making a decision.
Tests Spock’s logic to understand the best course of action before committing.
Quickly decides to help and orchestrates a plan involving disguises to enter the hospital.
Does not hesitate or show indecision despite the critical situation, demonstrating confidence.
Coordinates quietly with Bones and Gillian to aid a critically ill patient, showing concern for the patient's welfare.
Does not intervene in the interns' cynical and dismissive conversation about patient care, but acts to ensure patient receives help.
Leads the group efficiently through the hospital, communicates clearly about the patient's critical condition, and coordinates with Bones and Gillian.
Carries on with the plan without hesitation despite the unconventional hospital environment, demonstrating confidence and adaptability.
Calmly inquires about patient's symptoms and medical status, cooperates with Bones during emergency situation.
Allows Bones to take initiative using an experimental device without prior authorization, potentially disregarding protocol.
Blocks the young Doctor from leaving and physically restrains him to protect Bones and allow proper medical care.
Gives a swift judo chop to the young Doctor, then reassures others it was harmless.
Herbs nurses to a safe area and protects the Doctor by locking him away using his phaser to melt the lock.
Speaks encouragingly to Chekov as he begins to recover.
Blocks an incompetent doctor from interfering in a medical emergency, uses a quick Judo chop to neutralize him, then secures the area with his phaser to allow Bones to provide proper treatment.
Shows confident leadership and decisive action under pressure to protect a patient and medical personnel.
Shows concern for Chekov as he regains consciousness, speaks gently and encouragingly.
Assures policeman that Chekov will be okay, despite tense situation.
Mutters 'One little mistake...' after police show suspicion toward the team.
Uses the gurney as a battering ram to protect friends and ensure their escape from pursuers
Calms Nurse Gillian during a tense moment, reassuring her
Focuses on obtaining the radio frequency to track the whales, showing concern for their safety
Acknowledges Gillian's importance and thanks her sincerely despite being pressed for time.
Tells Gillian she can't come with him, showing a pragmatic, somewhat dismissive stance.
Admits to being tricked by Gillian with a tone that suggests some good-natured acceptance.
Calmly and clearly commands and coordinates the ship's crew during a complex mission, including checking on the safety of the whale tanks with concern.
Moves to Uhura to check on whale contact and immediately involves Gillian in the process.
Gives clear, encouraging commands to Uhura and Gillian, showing trust and confidence in the team.
Quickly assesses the situation upon receiving Uhura's report of an approaching whaling ship and commands immediate action to descend rapidly toward the whales.
Fails to prevent the whales from being threatened by the nearby whaling ship despite quick response, indicating possible limitations in preemptive strategy or timing.
Laughs warmly and shakes Spock's hand warmly, indicating approval and friendliness.
Expresses a thoughtful, somewhat tender reflection on humanity's destruction of whales, showing empathy and concern.
Acknowledges Gillian's point about whales and the 23rd Century knowledge with patience and openness.
Suggests Gillian might have lived longer if she stayed in her own time, implying a subtle warning or critique.
Calmly commands the crew despite turbulence and loss of control; directs multiple crew members to attempt recovery.

Directs the crew during a dangerous water landing, maintains focus on the mission despite the sinking ship, orders hatch to be blown, instructs Spock to ensure crew safety and emphasizes mission priorities.
Wrenches open a stuck cargo bay door underwater to rescue Scotty and Gillian, putting himself at risk.
Orders Scotty to go on ahead and close the hatch despite knowing he might be trapped himself.
Wrenches open the stuck emergency release and opens flooded cargo bay door to rescue Scotty and Gillian.
Voluntarily dives underwater to reach the explosive override despite risk of being trapped.
Gives clear orders to Scotty and Gillian to proceed to safety while he attempts the risky underwater task alone.
Swims desperately underwater to open the cargo bay and rescue survivors despite personal risk.
Watches the whales emerge and move away majestically, showing respect for living creatures.
Focuses intently on the mission and the probe's call without showing overt emotional distress or frustration.
Swims determinedly underwater despite danger, locates and opens the cargo bay doors to allow survivors to escape.
Shows situational awareness by quickly assessing escape routes underwater and surfacing safely with survivors.
Despite relief at survivors' safety, remains alert and continues to pursue unanswered calls of the Probe, showing persistence and focus.
Arrives at the wreckage and shows deep concern for fellow survivors, including Gillian and Spock.
Pledges guilty on behalf of all crew, accepts demotion without protest, acknowledges necessity of discipline, remains composed and respectful during sentencing
Shakes head in affection and disbelief after Gillian's goodbye, waits discreetly to allow Spock and Sarek a private moment
Encourages Scotty not to prejudge the Excelsior starship, demonstrating openness and respect for others' opinions.
Maintains calm and inclusive attitude towards crew members' differing views during uncertain circumstances.
Intercepts and analyzes the Probe's threatening communications. Identifies the only possible solution (Humpback Whale) with Captain Spock's help.
Communicates clearly and assertively with Starfleet Command, requesting confirmation and support.
Plans and announces an unprecedented attempt at time travel to solve the crisis, indicating boldness and problem-solving skills.
Commands emergency lights activation and requests damage report promptly after systems failure.
Acknowledges loss of control and orders 'rig for collision' to prepare for impact.
Attempts to communicate with Starfleet Command on emergency channel despite communication difficulties.
No evidence of panic; remains authoritative and methodical during crisis on the Saratoga bridge.
Secretly developing and test detonating the Genesis torpedo, a powerful new weapon, despite ongoing peace negotiations with the Klingons.
Reflects on the crew's uncertain situation with concern and acknowledges Doctor McCoy's thoughtful humor in naming the captured Klingon ship 'H.M.S. Bounty'.
Calls a unanimous vote to return to Earth and face consequences, showing respect for crew's opinions and responsibility.
Responds to Bones' complaint with a calm, slightly humorous remark, indicating tolerance and camaraderie.
Thanks Lt. Saavik and shows concern for her wellbeing, indicating sincerity and caring.

Asks for updates on Federation escort and comm channels, stays engaged and directs crew to continue on course despite uncertainty.
Notices odd absence of Federation vessels on patrol and actively queries crew about the status.
Responds quickly to Uhura's alert and demands visual confirmation of distress calls, demonstrating situational awareness and leadership.
Seeks Spock's analysis of the unprecedented energy wave affecting Earth, showing willingness to consult expertise and gather information before acting.

Understands and pursues Spock's suggestion that the transmission might be meant for life other than humans; asks Uhura to modify the Probe's signals based on environmental factors; actively leads and coordinates the effort to decode the message.
Does not question Spock's hypothesis and quickly initiates technical steps without apparent hesitation, showing trust and decisiveness.
Allows Spock and Bones to separate from him, giving orders for Bones to remain behind while Kirk pursues Spock; shows delegation and situational awareness.
Immediately initiates complex computations for time warp by instructing Spock to start calculations.
Confidently assesses the cargo bay size and directs Scotty to enclose it to hold water for whales.

Encourages crew with phrase 'May fortune favor the foolish', maintains steady command under pressure.

Orders shields and warp speed confidently despite warnings about the ship's integrity.

Immediately assesses the severity of the dilithium crystals' failing condition and seeks solutions.

Does not dismiss theoretical solutions despite risks and uncertainty, showing adaptive thinking.
No evident negative indicators in this excerpt; does not panic or make rash decisions.
Organizes the team efficiently by dividing into specialized groups and assigning roles based on expertise.
Issues clear operational protocols including use of phasers, communicators, and security measures such as removing rank insignia and maintaining radio silence with coded transmissions.
Acknowledges unknown cultural risks and prepares the team to expect surprises, showing situational awareness and caution.
Instructs his crew to stick together and be aware of their surroundings after arrival in an unfamiliar environment.

Reminds the crew to remember where they parked, demonstrating situational awareness and planning.
Frowns at the outdated use of money and quickly formulates a plan to acquire funds and organize the group, instructing them to spread out and avoid looking conspicuous.
Engages in a verbal altercation with a car driver and responds flusteredly with an insult.
Decides to sell valuable broken glasses pragmatically to fund their efforts despite sentimental value.

Sets clear budget limits and organizes teams efficiently before starting their separate tasks.

Engages attentively and seriously during the tour at the Maritime Cetacean Institute, paying stricter attention than others.
Engages thoughtfully in conversation about whales, demonstrating awareness of humanity's impact on the natural world.

Formulates a clear plan to beam both whales up together, identifying important logistical details for the mission.

Acknowledges the whales' right to be unhappy about humans' treatment of them.
Shows uncertainty regarding the whales' willingness to help, suggesting openness to cooperation.

Uses humor and light-heartedness under pressure to ease tension.

Engages in a subtle social maneuver to build rapport despite unclear or difficult circumstances.

Leaves quickly after paying, showing urgency but no evident coldness or indifference.

Calms Nurse Gillian down and takes control by contacting Scotty to get them out of the elevator, showing leadership and confidence in a tense situation.
Plans to track the whales by obtaining their radio frequency, indicating his focus on the mission and strategic mindset.
Shows decisive leadership by giving orders quickly and clearly, e.g., 'Beam me up, Scotty' and directing Sulu to go.
Expresses frustration about missing expected power but continues to proceed with the plan, showing patience under pressure.
Attempts to exclude Gillian from an important mission despite her insistence, showing some rigidity but also focus on mission success.
Admits he was tricked by Gillian, possibly indicating a lapse in judgment or underestimation of others' roles.
Gives clear, calm, and decisive orders during a complex and high-speed operation, coordinating multiple crew members and systems efficiently.
Expresses concern about the unprecedented weight of whales and water being beamed aboard, showing awareness of potential technical limits.
Commands the ship to hover instead of attacking whales, preventing harm to them.
Coordinates the ship's approach precisely by timing the dive speed and giving clear, confident commands to crew members to hover, de-cloak, and power up at exact moments.
Fails to prevent the harpoon from being fired at the whales, indicating a misjudgment or oversight about the situation despite knowing the whales are in danger.
Quiets the cheering crew to maintain focus and encourages Scotty with confidence and calm.
Orders Scotty to disengage the cloaking device to reveal their ship at a critical moment, demonstrating quick decision-making and confidence.
Calms his crew’s cheers and directs Scotty to initiate the transporter beam build-up, showing leadership and clear operational control under pressure.
Congratulates Scotty promptly with 'Well done, Mr. Scott.'
Shows concern for the danger to the ship by urging quick preparation and warning against jokes in a tense moment.
Takes initiative to personally accompany the guest to see the whales, demonstrating consideration and hospitality.
Directs the crew with clear, respectful commands without condescension.
Acknowledges Scotty's success and immediately asks how soon they can be ready for warp speed, showing situational awareness and urgency.
Orders Mr. Sulu to perform an impulse climb to increase altitude and avoid detection, demonstrating tactical skill.
Shows impatience with Scotty's joking when under pressure but quickly recovers focus, maintaining command presence.
Delegates control of the ship to Mr. Sulu and takes a direct role in an important mission task (bringing guest down to whales), indicating confidence and prioritization.
Asks Spock if the variable mass of whales and water has been accounted for in time re-entry program, indicating intelligent attention to technical details.
Laughs and expresses high spirits and confidence when Spock makes an educated guess despite uncertain data.
Acknowledges the irony of humanity destroying whales and its impact on the future, showing reflective insight.
Concedes Gillian's valid point about the difficulty of dealing with whales in the 23rd century after a thoughtful pause.
Admits realistically that chances of success are low in a somewhat resigned manner.
Responds promptly to crew's warnings and coordinates with Spock and Sulu under extreme pressure, giving clear and supportive commands.
Surveys an unknown and disorienting situation calmly and quickly attempts to gather information by questioning Spock about the braking thrusters.
Maintains communication under adverse technical conditions and transmits critical analysis and calls for input despite a distorted and failing communication link.
Attempts time travel and communicates the plan clearly to Starfleet before the power fails.
Maintains command presence by requesting situation reports and attempting to regain control despite severe system failures and no data.
Orders manual control when automated systems fail, demonstrating quick thinking under pressure.

Expresses frustration openly about lack of control and situational awareness ('Out of control, and blind as a bat!'), which may indicate momentary helplessness but realistic appraisal of the situation.
Arrives promptly at the wreckage, shows deep concern for crew and situation.
Questions why the probe doesn't answer or communicate as expected, demonstrating awareness and active monitoring.
Shows emotional frustration ('Why don't they sing, dammit!') indicating a personal investment and urgency.
Acknowledges that the credit for saving the Earth belongs to others, shows humility and realistic assessment.
Is brought before the Federation Council as an accused, indicating possible failure or controversy in his actions.
Does not immediately dismiss the Excelsior as a viable option despite Scotty's negative opinion; supports giving it a chance.
Leads the crew aboard the shuttlecraft toward an uncertain destination with calm observation and confidence.
Expresses collective pride and joy on seeing the freshly painted U.S.S. Enterprise and says, 'My friends... We've come home.'
Sits in Captain's chair and speaks with enthusiasm and camaraderie to Mr. Sulu, 'Let's see what she's got, Mr. Sulu.'
Returns to the Enterprise, resumes command confidently, initiates a trial run of the newly refitted starship and delivers a rousing captain's speech.
Attempts communication with Starfleet Command to warn of Earth's danger and to seek approval for the plan involving extinct Humpback Whales.
Initiates risky time travel mission to save Earth and its inhabitants.
